title: 111_hr2348
content: The "Financing Advanced and Superconducting Transmission Act of 2009" allows for 5-year depreciation for qualified advanced electric transmission property placed in service before January 1, 2017. Investment tax credit available for high efficiency transmission property and advanced electric transmission property. Investment tax credit available for qualified high efficiency transmission property and qualified advanced electric transmission property under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 offers an investment tax credit for qualified high efficiency transmission property, which includes high voltage overhead electric transmission lines and related facilities utilizing advanced conductor core technology determined by the Secretary of Energy. The investment tax credit for qualified high efficiency transmission property applies to transmission lines up to 765kV with power losses at least 30 percent lower than conventional ACSR conductors. The eligibility criteria include approval by an energy regulatory body and safe, cost-effective placement in a right of way. The investment tax credit for qualified high efficiency transmission property does not apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2016. Qualified advanced electric transmission property includes high voltage electric transmission cable utilizing advanced technology likely to become commercially viable within 10 years. Qualified advanced electric transmission property must be commercially viable within 10 years of the Financing Advanced and Superconducting Transmission Act of 2009, capable of transmitting at least 5 gigawatts over 300 miles with energy losses not exceeding 3%, and must not create an electromagnetic field. It must also be determined to be in the public interest by an energy regulatory body. Qualified advanced electric transmission property must be commercially viable within 10 years of the Financing Advanced and Superconducting Transmission Act of 2009, capable of transmitting at least 5 gigawatts over 300 miles with energy losses not exceeding 3%, and must not create an electromagnetic field. It must also be located safely and economically in a permanent underground right of way not to exceed 25 feet in width. For properties placed in service before January 1, 2015, with a length of not less than 150 miles, the energy percentage requirement is increased to 50 percent. The term 'qualified advanced electric transmission property' does not include any property placed in service after December 31, 2016. The amendments made by this section apply to periods after the date of the enactment of this Act, in taxable years ending after such date, for property placed in service after December 31, 2016.
